summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt for the week of September 26—October 1, 2011.

headline: American Graffiti
summary: On the closing day of his inaugural exhibit at Los Angeles's Museum of Contemporary Art, WSJ. spends a day in hot pursuit of museum director Jeffrey Deitch.

headline: Ingersoll-Rand, EnerNOC: Biggest Price Decliners (IR, ENOC)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: Express Scripts, Baidu: Money Flow Leaders (ESRX, BIDU)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: A Sweater To Live In
summary: Fall's cozy knits for men are perfect for a cool afternoon at the shore. (Even for her.) Six surfers from Montauk, New York's famous Ditch Plains beach warm to the idea.

headline: The Male Bag
summary: Until recently, men at work have had to choose between the all-business briefcase and the slacker messenger. Now the ideal carryall has arrived: the man tote.

headline: The 2010 Nobel Prizes
summary: Read about the winners and their work.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Sept. 30, 2011

headline: Let's Send Them Back
summary: After reading James Kirchick's "What American 'Political Prisoners'?"  (op-ed, Sept. 28) I have three words: Send them back!

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In today's photos, Russian cadets celebrate their school's anniversary, a shepherd walks past a grand palace in Afghanistan, Namibian skulls are returned from Germany, and more.

headline: Watchdog Clears SEC of Misconduct in Mark Cuban Probe
summary: An SEC inspector general report said there isn't sufficient evidence enforcement attorneys engaged in misconduct when they pursued an insider-trading case against Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban.

headline: Just Like Last Year's Giants: All Pitch, No Hit
summary: Despite big offensive names like Chase Utley and Ryan Howard, the Philadelphia Phillies are statistically similar to last year's strong-pitching, weak-hitting San Francisco Giants.

headline: Obama's Un-Neighborly Jobs Bill
summary: The 'buy-American' provision in President Obama's jobs bill strains relations with Canada.

headline: Primary Defiance
summary: The Republican presidential race might start narrowing down a month sooner than expected, thanks to Florida.

headline: Rise of an American Jihadist
summary: Al-Awlaki was linked to the Fort Hood, Texas, shooting spree and the botched bombing of a Detroit-bound jet on Christmas in 2009.

headline: Portfolio Rejiggering Rattles Markets
summary: Investors have been a trigger-happy lot this week, gobbling up risky securities one day and dumping them the next. A key factor behind the turmoil was the fact that it is the end of the quarter.

headline: Jenkins: Amazon and Our Giant Connected Heads
summary: In the future robots will have to do the work, because we'll be consuming media.

headline: In Libya, Have Truck, Will Proliferate
summary: 'The real war hasn't started yet,' explains a Libyan truck driver when asked why he is gathering weapons from a desert stockpile south of Sirte, Libya.

headline: Perry Steps Up Criticism of Romney
summary: Perry used an ostensible domestic-policy address Friday to lay out some of his sharpest criticisms of Romney.

headline: House GOP Changes Course on Infrastructure
summary: House Republicans abandoned plans to slash U.S. infrastructure spending and now say they are trying to find ways to pay for a multiyear highway-construction program backed by Senate Democrats and the White House.

headline: Living It Up In Death Valley
summary: A Very Urban Family Heads to the Desert for Weird Wildlife, Scorching Views, and Just a Hint of Danger.

headline: Panel's War-Waste Records Sealed
summary: The internal records of a congressionally mandated panel that reported staggering estimates of wasteful U.S. wartime spending will remain sealed to the public until 2031, officials confirmed, as the panel closed its doors on Friday.

headline: Francona Out as Red Sox Manager
summary: Two days after Boston completed its September collapse, the team declined to pick up the option on manager Terry Francona's contract.

headline: Dow Notches 12% Drop for the Third Quarter
summary: Stocks closed out the worst quarter in more than two years with a triple-digit dive in the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

headline: Solar Projects Get Funding Before Deadline
summary: The Energy Department said it closed $4.7 billion in loan guarantees and related deals for three large solar-power plants and a large rooftop solar project just hours before much of the funding for its loan-guarantee program was set to expire.

headline: Widening Gap
summary: Capitalization rates, used by real-estate investors to measure the annual return of income-producing properties, rose in August even as yields on 10-year Treasury notes dropped.

headline: iSoftStone Holdings, EnerNOC: Biggest Price Decliners (ISS, ENOC)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

headline: Noah Holdings, CNinsure: Biggest Price Gainers (NOAH, CISG)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: International Business Machines, BJ's Wholesale Club: Money Flow Leaders (IBM, BJ)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Banks Tout Fee-Free Cards
summary: As Bank of America's plan to charge customers to use debit  cards sparks public outrage, some banks are touting that their debit cards will remain free. But industry analysts say free debit cards could eventually go the way of free checked baggage on airlines.

headline: SEC Report Finds Problems at Credit Raters
summary: The SEC found that credit raters sometimes fail to manage conflicts of interest but didn't list any major regulatory issues, in the agency's first annual report on the firms.

headline: Investors Boost Bets Against Euro
summary: Even as the euro was rallying off of its lows, speculative investors increased their bets against the common currency this week.

headline: McGraw-Hill Taps Heidrick & Struggles To Find Education Unit Chief
summary: McGraw-Hill has picked executive recruiters Heidrick & Struggles to help find a chief executive for its education business following that unit's spinoff.

headline: Oil Prices Skid
summary: The front-month oil futures contract fell 3.6%, the end to a quarter that saw prices slide 17% on worries about the economy.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In Friday's photos, Russian cadets celebrate their school's anniversary, a shepherd walks past a grand palace in Afghanistan, Namibian skulls are returned from Germany, and more.

headline: Watchdog: Regulators Shouldn't Relax Bank Capital Rules
summary: A government watchdog said regulators must remain vigilant against demands to relax capital requirements while taking on more risk.

headline: Corporate Bond Issuance Slows
summary: Corporate borrowers issued only $157.9 billion of investment-grade bonds in the last three months, the slowest pace since the second quarter of 2010, as the lingering threat of a Greek debt default constrained sellers as well as buyers.

headline: Red-Hot Metals Could Burn LME's Suitors
summary: The member-owned London Metal Exchange has received a preliminary offer so attractive it's considering a sale, and has opened up the field to other bidders. But LME's suitors should be careful not to get their fingers burned.

headline: BofA's Online Banking Has Access Issues
summary: Some Bank of America customers are experiencing issues while trying to access their online banking accounts, with the website "operating slower than usual."

headline: The Hunt for Al Qaeda
summary: The death of Anwar al-Awlaki, one of the U.S.'s most-wanted terrorists, is the latest blow to al Qaeda's leadership. Take a look back.

headline: Hitachi-LG Data Storage To Plead Guilty To Bid Rigging
summary: Hitachi-LG Data Storage will plead guilty to rigging bids and fixing prices on optical disk drives used in computers and other electronic devices, and will pay a $21 million criminal fine, the Justice Department said.

headline: Gold Sank 11% in September
summary: Gold settled slightly higher on the day at $1,622.30 a troy ounce but futures dropped 11% in September.

headline: Apotheker to Get $7.2 Million From H-P
summary: The company also agreed to pay new CEO Meg Whitman an annual salary of $1, as well as an option to purchase 1.9 million H-P shares.

headline: European Stocks Sink
summary: The Stoxx Europe 600 index fell 1.2% to 226.18, bringing its quarterly loss to 17%, as worries about rising inflation in the euro zone, weak German retail sales and contracting Chinese manufacturing activity all hurt sentiment.

headline: USDA to Resurvey Wheat, Oats Growers
summary: The Department of Agriculture will resurvey growers of wheat, barley and oats in several states due to harvest delays.

headline: Corus Plots Course Post-Bankruptcy
summary: Once slated for liquidation, Corus Bankshares received court approval for its bankruptcy-exit plan that calls for the former Illinois bank-holding company to emerge as a real-estate investment firm.

headline: Mizuho to Buy 15% of Vietcombank
summary: A unit of Japan's Mizuho Financial Group agreed to buy a 15% stake in Vietnam's largest listed bank by market value for $567.3 million, in a deal that could foster increased investment by Japanese companies into the South East Asian economy.

headline: International Men of Mystery
summary: A remembrance of playboys past: Let's raise a glass in memory of the world's great ladies' men.

headline: Allianz Global Investors CEO Sees Euro-Zone Solution in Time
summary: The euro zone's credit crisis will likely be resolved in an orderly fashion, although the pace of a long-term resolution will lag market expectations, said the head of Allianz Global Investors.

headline: Quarter Ends With a Thud in Europe, Asia
summary: European shares fell sharply and most Asian markets declined, putting an exclamation point on a bleak third quarter.

headline: Pilgrim's Pride, Princeton National Bancorp: Biggest Price Gainers (PPC, PNBC)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: China's Low-Cost Image Fades
summary: Rapidly rising wages in China have reached the point at which foreign manufacturers need to give up on the notion of China as a low-cost production base, a senior Hyundai executive said.

headline: Austria Backs Rescue-Fund Changes
summary: Austria's parliament ratified the amended euro-zone rescue fund, as expected, putting the currency bloc on track to increase the size and expand the powers of the EFSF.

headline: TeliaSonera Awarded Damages in Telecoms Spat
summary: Swedish telecommunications firm TeliaSonera said it has been awarded $932 million in damages following a conflict with a rival shareholder over control of Turkey's largest mobile operator.

headline: Greek Aid Talks Roll On Amid Protests
summary: Talks between international creditors and the Greek government on fresh aid became overshadowed by protests and resistance from state-owned companies.

headline: Cephalon Gets Second Subpoena in Week
summary: For the second time in a week, Cephalon received a subpoena from federal prosecutors seeking information about certain drugs.

headline: Ireland's Impressive Progress
summary: Ireland's bonds now yield less than when Dublin received a bailout in November 2010, despite the escalation in the euro-zone debt crisis since the summer. That offers a flicker of hope.

headline: Japan Output Continues Recovery, but Outlook Murky
summary: Japanese industrial production continues to bounce back, rising for the fifth-straight month in August, but the outlook remains murky.

headline: Chrysler Plant Joins National Contract
summary: Workers at a Chrysler engine plant voted Friday to end their separate labor contract with the company, a factory official said, eliminating the possibility of a strike that could have disrupted the labor negotiations between Chrysler and the UAW.

headline: John H. Cochrane: Last Chance to Save the Euro
summary: A Greek default won't destroy Europe's currency. Bailouts will.

headline: EU Urges Slovakia to Pass Bailout Reforms
summary: The European Commission urged Slovakia to approve reforms to the euro-zone bailout mechanism and deliver on the commitment made by the country's government in the July 21 agreement.

headline: Nabucco Project Gains New Backing
summary: A day before a key deadline in the development of a major new gas pipeline, Bayerngas said it intends to join the European Union-backed Nabucco pipeline project.

headline: Deutsche Bank Glum on Economy
summary: Deutsche Bank's chief executive painted a bleak picture of the global economy, saying the world's economy is on the brink of recession—with Europe and the U.S. set to feel the pain for quarters to come.

headline: Italian Business Lobby Calls for Action on Economy
summary: Italy's business elite demanded rapid and bold action by the government to avoid what they called an "ineluctable slide into economic and social decline."

headline: Casino Looks to Latin America
summary: France's Groupe Casino plans to expand in Latin America through acquisitions made by its Colombia-based unit, Almacenes Exito, the unit's Chief Executive Gonzalo Restrepo said.

headline: New Delhi's Effigy Market
summary: Titarpur is one of New Delhi's largest effigy markets, and it is now abuzz with artisans preparing Ravana demon king figures for Dussehra Festival. Some snapshots.

headline: Hyundai India to Open Eon Bookings Saturday
summary: The India unit of Hyundai Motor will start taking customer orders Saturday for its Eon small car, seeking to challenge market leader Maruti Suzuki India's Alto car.

headline: India Monsoon Rains 1% Above Average
summary: India's monsoon rains at the end of the June-September season were 1% above the 50-year average, raising hopes of improved crop supplies at a time when the country is battling high food prices.

headline: India April-June Current Account Deficit Widens to $14.1 Billion
summary: India's April-June current account deficit widened to $14.1 billion from $12.0 billion a year earlier due to a moderation in receipts from transportation, software and business services, raising concerns of a worsening external balance situation, central bank data showed.

headline: India Telecom Minister: Seeking New Bandwidth Auction
summary: India's Department of Telecommunications is in discussions with the federal finance ministry to hold another round of auctions for bandwidth to provide wireless broadband services, Telecommunications Minister Kapil Sibal said.

headline: Japan Raps Barclays Capital
summary: Barclays Capital Japan said it has been ordered by the Financial Services Agency to suspend some of its operations for 10 days due to a technical glitch on its order system.

headline: Indraprastha to Raise CNG Prices
summary: Indraprastha Gas said it will raise auto gas prices by about 7%, effective Saturday, due to an increase in the price of imported liquefied natural gas and the rupee's depreciation against the dollar.

headline: Japan Auto Output Rises Above Pre-Quake Level
summary: Japan's auto production rose in August from a year earlier, eclipsing the pre-quake level of a year earlier for the first time since the March disasters, as car makers closed in on a complete restoration of their once-crippled parts supply chains.

headline: Jardines Taps Keswick Scion to Take Helm
summary: Jardines, whose history as an opium trader made it instrumental in Hong Kong's cessation to Britain in the 19th century, chose Ben Keswick to take over as managing director of the business empire.

headline: India Shares Slide 1.5%
summary: Indian shares fell sharply to post their biggest quarterly loss since the financial crisis of 2008, as investors across Asia and Europe remained cautious over efforts to stabilize the euro zone's debt crisis. The Sensex has fallen almost 20% in 2011 so far.

headline: India Cabinet Approves Mining Bill
summary: The Indian cabinet approved the draft of a law that seeks to attract investments in mining by simplifying rules and smoothening land acquisitions, but industry executives said some of the proposals were negative.

headline: Southeast Asia in Pictures
summary: Typhoon Nesat pummels the Philippines, a fire engulfs a Singapore oil refinery and more.

headline: Japan to Expand Yen-Intervention War Chest
summary: Japan's finance minister sent a fresh warning against the yen's strength with a plan to expand the nation's currency-market intervention arsenal.

headline: Alstom's China Chief Denies Role in Crashes
summary: The chief executive of Alstom's China operations said its local joint venture supplied hardware but not signaling technology to a Chinese rail line where a deadly high-speed train crash occurred in July.

headline: Moody's Unlikely to Change India Outlook
summary: Moody's Investors Service is unlikely to change its rating outlook on India for now, though the extent of the increase in the government's borrowing target is a surprise, a credit analyst at the ratings company said.

headline: Koutons' Lenders Approve Debt Restructuring Plan
summary: Koutons Retail India said its lenders have approved the company's proposal to recast its debt.

headline: Reliance Power Gets RBI OK for Overseas Loans
summary: Reliance Power said it has received approval from India's central bank to raise $2.2 billion in loans from U.S. and Chinese banks to part-fund a power project.

headline: Japan's Monex Looks for Growth in China
summary: Japan's Monex Group is aggressively positioning itself to tap into the potentially massive Chinese online brokerage market, with an aim to eventually rake in at least one-third of its profits from China, including Hong Kong.

headline: ABN Amro Follows Deutsche With Bond Issue
summary: ABN Amro is planning to sell a senior unsecured bond on Friday, just one day after the market for this type of long-term debt reopened for European banks.

headline: India Minister to Push for Infrastructure Status for Telecom Tower Segment
summary: India's telecommunications minister, Kapil Sibal, said he will push the government to consider offering infrastructure status to the capital-starved and debt-ridden telecom tower segment.

headline: Lupus Drug Suffers U.K. Setback
summary: Lupus drug Benlysta, from GlaxoSmithKline and Human Genome Sciences, doesn't represent value for money, Britain's health-care watchdog said, and shouldn't be made available on the publicly funded National Health Service.

headline: India Bosch: About 2,500 Workers on Strike
summary: Bosch said about 2,500 workers at its south India plant have gone on an "illegal" strike, forcing the auto parts maker to shut operations at the facility.

headline: Investors Can't Shake That Volatile Feeling
summary: Persistent volatility has thrown investors for a loop. Unless this fever breaks soon, the economy may take the kind of turn that leaves investors really feeling sick.

headline: Polymetal Plans to List on LSE
summary: OAO Polymetal, Russia's second-biggest gold producer, said it plans to swap its Russian listing for a premium listing on the main market of the London Stock Exchange.

headline: India in Pictures
summary: Garba night, a woman takes on the 'well of death', the cremation of an army officer killed in Kashmir, and more.

headline: TomTom Eyes Clearer Path Ahead
summary: Dutch navigation-system producer TomTom expects the decline in sales of its personal-navigation devices will stabilize as its customers start replacing devices with the latest models.

headline: Maruti Suzuki Incurs Heavy Loss on Labor Unrest
summary: Maruti Suzuki India has lost about six billion rupees ($123 million) in vehicle production in a month as labor unrest at one of its factories hit output of three of its key car models, a spokesman for the country's largest car maker by sales said.

headline: German Retail Sales Disappoint
summary: German retail sales fell much more than expected in August, although analysts said the mood among German consumers remains broadly positive.

headline: France's EFSF Sang-froid
summary: The Bundestag voted overwhelmingly in favor of the euro-zone rescue fund Thursday but only after vigorous debate. What a contrast to France, where the prospect of spending taxpayers' money on a bailout has barely raised an eyebrow.

headline: In Spanish IPO, No Lucky Numbers
summary: Spain's postponement of an offering for its state lottery is a bad sign for Europe's moribund IPO markets. For European countries hoping to raise cash by selling state assets, it is an even worse omen.

headline: Champions League Twenty20
summary: Kolkata Knight Riders beat Royal Challengers Bangalore by nine wickets to win their first match in this year's Champions League Twenty20 tournament. Some snapshots.

headline: Medical Report Prompts French Probe
summary: French prosecutors said they had launched an investigation to determine whether anyone exploited the mental and physical weaknesses of France's richest woman, L'Oréal heiress Liliane Bettencourt, to obtain money or other benefits.

headline: Austria Set to Approve Fund Expansion
summary: The Austrian parliament is expected to ratify the amended euro-zone rescue fund Friday following positive nods from Finland and Germany.

headline: Domestic Helpers Win Ruling
summary: A Hong Kong court ruled unconstitutional the immigration ordinance that blocks foreign domestic workers from obtaining permanent residency.

headline: Strides Arcolab to Launch Cancer Treatment Injection in U.S.
summary: Strides Arcolab said its unit has received U.S. regulatory approval for a generic version of cancer treating paclitaxel injections, which the Indian company will launch immediately through partner Pfizer.

headline: Chaoda Executives Deny Insider Dealing Charges
summary: Chaoda Modern Agriculture (Holdings) said its chairman and chief financial officer deny having engaged in insider dealing as the Hong Kong government has alleged.

headline: Reliance Denies Role in Telecom Scam
summary: Indian billionaire Anil Ambani's Reliance Group denied that any of the group companies, including Reliance Telecom, illegally benefited from the 2008 sale of telecommunication licenses that has now turned into the country's biggest corruption scandal.

headline: Reliance Capital Gets RBI Nod For Stake Sale In Life Insurance Unit
summary: Reliance Capital said it has received the Reserve Bank of India's approval for a proposed stake sale in its life insurance unit to Japan-based Nippon Life Insurance.

headline: India Raises Borrowing Aim
summary: The Indian government raised its borrowing target for the current fiscal year by 528 billion rupees ($10.8 billion), surprising the market and fueling worries that it may even overshoot the new estimate because of muted revenue growth amid a slowing economy and swelling subsidies.

headline: CapitaMalls: Initial Approval for Hong Kong Secondary Listing
summary: Shopping mall developer CapitaMalls Asia Ltd. has received approval-in-principle to proceed with a secondary listing on the Hong Kong stock exchange.

headline: Space Adventure for $200,000 a Seat
summary: Virgin Galactic is offering a lucky few a ride in to space for $200,000 a seat, with prospective tourists from Japan, Singapore and Malaysia snapping up tickets.

headline: Mahindra Launches XUV500
summary: Mahindra & Mahindra introduced a new sport-utility vehicle, the XUV500, in an attempt to bolster its presence in the expanding local market for SUVs and also challenge global auto makers in overseas markets.

headline: Honda Launches Brio in India
summary: Honda Motor introduced its second hatchback and cheapest car yet in India, as the auto maker seeks to challenge the dominance of Maruti Suzuki India and Hyundai Motor in the country's most popular vehicle segment.

headline: S&P, Fitch Downgrade New Zealand
summary: S&P and Fitch both downgraded New Zealand's government bonds, citing its worsening debt and the costs of earthquake recovery.

headline: China Launches Space Module
summary: China launched an experimental module to lay the groundwork for a future space station, underscoring its ambitions to become a major space power.

headline: Chávez Denies Health Setback Rumors
summary: Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez, suffering from cancer, on Thursday denied reports that he is gravely ill, appearing on live television to talk about everything from U.S. imperialism to the finer points of throwing a curveball.

headline: Banks Plan New Debit Card Fees
summary: The beleaguered banking industry, which has been raising fees and doing away with free services, has a new target: debit-card users.

headline: Flick or Treat? Halloween Horror Movies
summary: Snapshot: From the South Pole to the North Woods, a selection

headline: David Slijper Captures a Moment for Himself
summary: When he isn't busy shooting ad campaigns, magazine covers or runway shows, British fashion photographer David Slijper snaps up some quiet personal space over the weekend to unwind.

headline: Downtown Los Angeles Living
summary: Talent agent Thor Bradwell and interior designer and artist Lars Gradel have made their latest Los Angeles home their most lavish. The three-story penthouse loft has 14-foot ceilings and a roof deck with a private 45-foot-long infinity swimming pool and hot tub.

headline: Where Is Manmohan Singh?
summary: New Delhi's leadership vacuum prompts feuds and confusion.

headline: The Long View on Treasury Yields
summary: After enjoying an effective annual return of 15.2% for three decades, those lucky enough to have timed the top on 30-year bonds may find themselves feeling wistful come Oct. 27, when the bond matures. Where on earth will they find something remotely comparable in which to roll their capital?

headline: Why Amazon Promotes Its Rivals
summary: While attention lately has been focused on Amazon.com's launch of a tablet PC, the e-commerce giant has been quietly taking bolder steps in another part of its business.

headline: Drug Firms Up Ante in Japan
summary: Western drug makers are stepping up their race to gain a bigger presence in Japan, the world's second-largest pharmaceuticals market after the U.S.

headline: A New Address, a New Project
summary: A Los Angeles couple dress up their latest, and largest, downtown loft.

headline: N.Y. Curtis vs. Detroit Curtis
summary: The past and present of Curtis Granderson's baseball life are set to collide when the Yankees and Tigers open the American League Division Series on Friday night at Yankee Stadium.

headline: 'Mad Men' Support Charity
summary: If there was ever a television cast that fit with a sobering charity function, it would be the cast of "Mad Men," which hosted the annual Rape Foundation Brunch this weekend at Green Acres Estate, the home of the investor Ron Burkle in Beverly Hills, Calif.

headline: Nokia to Cut 3,500 Jobs
summary: Finnish handset maker Nokia said it will cut up to 3,500 jobs globally as it realigns its business, scales down and refocuses its manufacturing operations.

headline: 'The Iliad': It's Not All Greek to Him
summary: The "rock star" of translators produces a daring new version of the epic poem; the "B" word.

headline: Cromartie's Year: Goat to Hero to Goat
summary: Cornerback Antonio Cromartie has put together a wacky, Jekyll and Hyde-like showing throughout the first three weeks of the NFL season.

headline: A Thin Line on Skirts
summary: Note to women in the South Slope, Brooklyn: Think twice before wearing shorts or skirts at night. That's the message some women say police officers are spreading in response to a string of unsolved sexual attacks.

headline: Where the Bass Player Went Off To: Bill Wyman
summary: The former Rolling Stone talks about a new CD box set with the Rhythm Kings.

headline: Italian Art Sales: From the Ornate to the Sublime
summary: Italian art takes center stage in October with the Florence Biennale Internationale dell'Antiquariato and London auctions of 20th-century Italian works.

headline: What's News—
summary: Here are the top business and finance stories for Europe.

headline: What's On Around Europe
summary: The Weekend Journal's guide to exhibitions, concerts and events across Europe.

headline: Vote Gives European Stocks a Lift
summary: European stocks shook off early weakness to end higher, and the euro rose, as upbeat U.S. data and Germany's approval of the European Financial Stability Facility extension propped up confidence—for now, at least.

headline: Christie's Positions Face Scrutiny
summary: Those clamoring for the New Jersey governor to enter the presidential race generally cite his reputation. Less mentioned are his views on issues that reflect the relatively liberal shade of his state.

headline: Bahrain Protester Sentenced to Death
summary: Bahrain's National Safety Court sentenced a man to death for allegedly killing a policeman and handed down hefty jail terms to 20 doctors and nurses, in another round of punishments for those involved with the antigovernment uprising earlier in the year.

headline: Dizzy's Welcomes an Old Friend
summary: This week's jazz calendar leads off with Gerald Wilson and the Juilliard Jazz Orchestra and moves on to Karen Akers at the Oak Room and Cassandra Wilson at Rose Hall.

headline: Jason Pack and Sami Zaptia: First Revolution, Now Democracy
summary: The world is watching Libya's transition.

headline: History of an American Calamity
summary: How, in the United States, land of the free, could Prohibition ever have come to be?

headline: For Baldessari, Art Imitates Art
summary: Though California artist John Baldessari is often classified as a conceptual artist, and sometimes lumped in with the Pop Art movement, his exhibition of new work, "Double Feature," at Berlin's Sprüth Magers Gallery, eludes pigeonholing.

headline: Stephen Moore: Flat Is the New Fair
summary: Is President Obama paving the way for GOP tax reform?

headline: New York Film Festival's New Broadway Bijou
summary: Alexander Payne's "The Descendants," the North American debut of Roman Polanski's "Carnage" and the world premiere of "My Week With Marilyn," starring Michelle Williams as Marilyn Monroe, are coming to the New York Film Festival at its newly expanded location.

headline: When Joyous Attitude Becomes Form
summary: The assault on pretension in sculptor Barry Flanagan;s later work is more than matched by the joyous humor evident in a new show at Tate Britain, "Early Works 1965-1982."

headline: A Director Casts About for Clues
summary: In his memoir, director Michael Lindsay-Hogg muses about working with the Beatles or Glenda Jackson or on 'Brideshead Revisited'—and wondering who his father really was. Moira Hodgson reviews.

headline: Miami Heat's Alonzo Mourning Lists His Coral Gables Home
summary: Retired Miami Heat player Alonzo Mourning and his wife, Tracy, have put their Coral Gables, Fla., estate on the market for $14.5 million. Plus, designer Donald J. Pliner has listed his Miami Beach home for $19.9 million, and the La Jolla, Calif., estate of the late scientist Roger Revelle's family has come back on the market for $12.5 million.

headline: Game 1 May Decide All
summary: The showdown of aces between Justin Verlander and CC Sabathia will likely determine the Yankees' fate in the series.

headline: Richard Riordan: Saving Catholic Education
summary: Over 50 years, the U.S. Catholic school population has dropped by almost two-thirds.

headline: Disability Cases Delayed to Meet Goals
summary: Some Social Security workers were told to set aside disability cases this week, with the slowdown allowing managers to boost their performance numbers for the coming fiscal year.

headline: Santander Looks to Diversify
summary: Banco Santander CEO Alfredo Sáenz said he expects profit to improve gradually over the next three years on strong-earnings growth in Latin America and Poland.

headline: The Mercurial Rise of an Unheralded Rookie
summary: Giants linebacker Jacquian Williams has turned his teammates' heads with strong play and a tireless work ethic.

headline: Pimco Cuts Appetite for Risk
summary: Pacific Investment Management is dialing back exposure to riskier assets and moving to relatively high-quality investments like emerging-market debt, reflecting its concerns about the global economic outlook.

headline: Small Homes in the Great Outdoors -- Photos
summary: Tour homes in East Hampton, N.Y., Spring Island, S.C., and Okeechobee, Fla.
